resources.string: This device doesn\'t support Camera2 API.
This device doesn\'t support Camera2 API.
There is a new model available to download

A rounded hand hold with no lip or edge of any kind. The secret to slopers is to get as much surface area of the hand on the climbing hold as possible. Slopers work best when your body is below the hold

Used to mark the start of a climbing route, your hands must start on both marked holds and feet off the floor to begin a climb. Hand starts can be marked as small metal discs, tape in a V-shape, or other methods. If you are unsure then ask a staff member at your climbing centre.
Imagine the top of a door frame. A crimp is a small hold with a positive edge for your fingers. Crimps require finger strength which can take a while to gain.

The kind of hold that you\'ll grip by squeezing with your fingers and thumb placed on opposing sides. Pinches come in all different sizes and shapes. Some are small and require good finger strength and some are larger and easier.
A climber\'s best friend. Big and deep, it\'s the kind of hold you can get your fingers securely behind. When using a jug. Keep your arms straight to avoid them getting tired too quickly
A hold with a hole in it. Hole size varies from being able to fit 4 fingers in to only 1 finger.
A hold consisting of multiple pinch holds.
